questions.neutral: Do the streets feel heavier today?

hobby.message: The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.
Still chasing ghosts with analog photography?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Yes. The air is uneasy, everyone feels it.
I keep to myself best I can.
Restoring old typewriters, actually. Quiet work, these days.
Even that's been harder with all the shouting lately.
It's not just you. Feels changed out there.
I prefer quieter things at home, like typewriter repairs.
Metal and ink, something from before all this digital noise.
Tensions even seep into my workspace lately.
Took me twice as long to fix a ribbon last night.
Heavier, yes. People are watching each other closer.
I try to lose myself restoring antique typewriters. Calms the nerves.
Each key is a little puzzle, you know.
But last night, the uproar over the broadcast bled into my room.
Couldn’t focus—hands shaky, too much noise outside.
Had to leave the machine unfinished for once.
Definitely heavier. Even my building—neighbors whispering, arguing about all these leaked BCI scores.
Normally, I'd spend an evening cleaning a Remington or lubricating an Adler mechanism.
Restoring typewriters is the one thing that clears my mind.
But the protests, accusations, talk of rigged votes—it crept right in.
Put me on edge; even hit a wrong key twice.
Strange feeling—my quiet hobby turned as unsettled as the street.
Makes you realize privacy isn’t just about data.
Heavier’s the word. Streets echo rumors now, not news.
I've spent years—decades—restoring antique typewriters, all makes, all eras.
Been keeping a handwritten journal, too—habit from a time before all these systems.
Normally, fixing a stubborn ribbon or realigning a spring quiets the city down for me.
But since the broadcast about the vote scandal, there’s been shouting outside, banging on doors.
People used to scoff at my ink-stained fingers—now they eye me, wondering about my rating.
Last night, hands trembling, I couldn’t finish even a simple carriage reset.
Funny how even private habits catch the city’s fever, these days.
hobby_answer: Another typewriter, yes. Routine helps.
Most days I just clean, nothing more.
Prefer simple machines, no stories.
There's too much noise lately. Hard to focus.
Better to keep fingers busy than opinions.
Yes, typewriter maintenance again. It keeps hands steady.
Old keys, old ribbons. Familiar steps.
No one interrupts a man fixing things—usually.
Voting week made neighbors suspicious.
I'm careful even with harmless hobbies these days.
Not everything needs broadcasting.
That's right. Cleaning an Adler from '37 yesterday.
Getting harder with everyone so wound up lately.
Angry shouts distracted me. Even fumbled the typebar alignment.
This vote mess put everyone on edge.
I used to enjoy the quiet restoration.
Now I glance at the door between repairs.
Strange times for simple pleasures.
Exactly. Cleaning and realigning typewriters—best way to spend an evening.
Had an Olympia jam up when the riots started outside.
Neighbors pounded on doors over the voting scandal—spilled ink everywhere.
Couldn’t concentrate, so put it all away half-finished.
These machines remind me of steadier days.
Repairs used to settle my nerves. Not so much lately.
Even hobbies draw suspicion, it seems.
Still, I keep a few in working order. Just in case.
You know me. Nothing steadies the mind like restoring a classic Underwood or Adler.
Spent hours last week cleaning the segment shift while crowds chanted outside.
Used to make catalogues of old machine serials, before the BCI made everything trackable.
Election night, I couldn’t finish a page—hands shook with every siren.
Now even picking up spare parts attracts strange looks.
Sometimes I write thoughts on onionskin, then burn them—habit from Council days.
The vote manipulation leak made everyone lose faith. Distrust is everywhere.
Typewriters felt safe; now even that solace is tainted.
Funny, I never thought metal and ink would feel controversial.
